conclusion: Two particles, A and B, start from rest at the same point and move in the same direction.
The graph is a velocity-time graph with time on the x-axis and velocity on the y-axis, showing two lines for particles A and B.
Particle A starts from rest, increases to 2v₀ at t=t₀, decreases to zero at t=2t₀, and becomes negative reaching -v₀ at t=3t₀.
Particle B starts from rest, reaches v₀ at t=3t₀, maintains v₀ until t=5t₀, and decreases to zero at t=6t₀.
Positions of particles can be determined by integrating their velocity curves over time.
The distance between particles is s(t) = s_A(t) - s_B(t).
To find when they are farthest apart, find the maximum value of s(t) when ds/dt = 0.
ds/dt = v_A - v_B; find when v_A - v_B = 0.
Maximum separation occurs when the relative velocity changes sign, i.e., v_A - v_B = 0.
Find the time when v_A = v_B.
The velocity curves intersect at some point on the graph.
The relative distance is the integral of (v_A - v_B) dt from t=0 to t.
To find the maximum of s(t), take its derivative and set it to zero: ds/dt = v_A - v_B = 0.
Find when v_A = v_B by looking at the graph.
The intersection of v_A and v_B appears around t=2t₀.
Express v_A and v_B as functions of time.
For particle A: v_A = 2v₀ * t / t₀ from t=0 to t=t₀.
For particle A: v_A = 2v₀ - (2v₀ / t₀) (t - t₀) from t=t₀ to t=2t₀.
For particle A: v_A = - (2v₀ / t₀) (t - 2t₀) from t=2t₀ to t=3t₀.
